currentDoc:
How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

In my opinion, the term "screens" is unhelpful. Long before the social media age and the pandemic, people sat at home glued to TV screens for hour after hour.  There are three main purposes of looking at a screen, for information, social connection and entertainment. If we divide out screen time to embrace social media and education, we are putting them to good use. And as Entertainment has come in large part via screens since relatively early in the twentieth century.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the term "screens" is unhelpful. Long before the social media age and the pandemic, people sat at home glued to TV screens for hour after hour.  There are three main purposes of looking at a screen, for information, social connection and entertainment. If we divide out screen time to embrace social media and education, we are putting them to good use. And as for entertainment, this come in large part via screens since relatively early in the twentieth century.
In my opinion, screen time is as beneficial as any other leisure activity.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the term "screens" is unhelpful. Long before the social media age and the pandemic, people sat at home glued to TV screens for hour after hour.  There are three main purposes of looking at a screen, for information, social connection and entertainment. If we divide out screen time to embrace social media and education, we are putting them to good use. And as for entertainment, this come in large part via screens since relatively early in the twentieth century.
In my opinion, screen time is as beneficial as any other leisure activity.
 The mechanics and ergonomics of screen use are another issue. Hun

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the term "screens" is unhelpful. Long before the social media age and the pandemic, people sat at home glued to TV screens for hour after hour.  There are three main purposes of looking at a screen, for information, social connection and entertainment. If we divide out screen time to embrace social media and education, we are putting them to good use. And as for entertainment, this come in large part via screens since relatively early in the twentieth century.
In my opinion, screen time is as beneficial as any other leisure activity.
 The mechanics and ergonomics of screen use are another issue. Hunching over a screen is unhealthy, as is long=tern squinting at a scre

If we divide out screen time to embrace social media and education, we are putting them to good use. And as for entertainment, this come in large part via screens since relatively early in the twentieth century.
In my opinion, screen time is as beneficial as any other leisure activity.
 The mechanics and ergonomics of screen use are another issue. Hunching over a screen is unhealthy, as is long-term squinting at a screen and its attendant physical i

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

In my opinion, the term "screens" is unhelpful. Long before the social media age and the pandemic, people sat at home glued to TV screens for hour after hour.  There are three main purposes of looking at a screen, for information, social connection and entertainment. If we divide out screen time to embrace social media and education, we are putting them to good use. And as for entertainment, this come in large part via screens since relatively early in the twentieth century.
In my opinion, screen time is as beneficial as any other leisure activity.

In my opinion, the term "screens" is unhelpful. Long before the social media age and the pandemic, people sat at home glued to TV screens for hour after hour.  There are three main purposes of looking at a screen, for information, social connection and entertainment. If we divide out screen time to embrace social media and education, we are putting them to good use. And as for entertainment, this come in large part via screens since relatively early in the twentieth century.
In my opinion, screen time is as beneficial as any other leisure activity.
 The mechanics and ergonomics of screen use are another issue. Hunching over a screen is unhealthy, as is long-term squinting at a screen and its attendant physical immobility. But these are practical, not moral issues. Improved AI and

If we divide out screen time to embrace social media and education, we are putting them to good use. And as for entertainment, this come in large part via screens since relatively early in the twentieth century.
In my opinion, screen time is as beneficial as any other leisure activity.
 The mechanics and ergonomics of screen use are another issue. Hunching over a screen is unhealthy, as is long-term squinting at a screen and its attendant physical immobility. But these are practical, not moral issues. Improved AI and AI and robotic integration is lkel

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the term "screens" is unhelpful. Long before the social media age and the pandemic, people sat at home glued to TV screens for hour after hour.  There are three main purposes of looking at a screen, for information, social connection and entertainment. If we divide out screen time to embrace social media and education, we are putting them to good use. And as for entertainment, this come in large part via screens since relatively early in the twentieth century.
In my opinion, screen time is as beneficial as any other leisure activity.
 The mechanics and ergonomics of screen use are another issue. Hunching over a screen is unhealthy, as is long-term squinting at a screen and its attendant physical immobility. But these are practical, not moral issues. Improved AI and AI and robotic integration is lkely to put the main funstions of screen time more woth the physical wor

But these are practical, not moral issues. Improved AI and AI and robotic integration is likely to integrthe main functions of screen time to  the physical world in a relatively healthy manner.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the term "screens" is unhelpful. Long before the social media age and the pandemic, people sat at home glued to TV screens for hour after hour.  There are three main purposes of looking at a screen, for information, social connection and entertainment. If we divide out screen time to embrace social media and education, we are putting them to good use. And as for entertainment, this come in large part via screens since relatively early in the twentieth century.
In my opinion, screen time is as beneficial as any other leisure activity.
 The mechanics and ergonomics of screen use are another issue. Hunching over a screen is unhealthy, as is long-term squinting at a screen and its attendant physical immobility. But these are practical, not moral issues. Improved AI,  AR and robotics  is likely to progressively integrate the main functions of screen time to  the physical world in a relatively healthy manner.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the term "screens" is unhelpful. Long before the social media age and the pandemic, people sat at home glued to TV screens for hour after hour.  There are three main purposes of looking at a screen, for information, social connection and entertainment. If we divide out screen time to embrace social media and education, we are putting them to good use. And as for entertainment, this come in large part via screens since relatively early in the twentieth century.
In my opinion, screen time is as beneficial as any other leisure activity.
 The mechanics and ergonomics of screen use are another issue. Hunching over a screen is unhealthy, as is long-term squinting at a screen and its attendant physical immobility. But these are practical, not moral issues. Improved AI,  AR and robotics are likely to progressively integrate the main functions of screen time with the physical world in a relatively healthy manner. 

In time, whole populations might live mostly in virtual environments without any significant increase in health problems. The benefits of physical exercise and fresh air will still apply, and e.

 The mechanics and ergonomics of screen use are another issue. Hunching over a screen is unhealthy, as is long-term squinting at a screen and its attendant physical immobility. But these are practical, not moral issues. Improved AI,  AR and robotics are likely to progressively integrate the main functions of screen time with the physical world in a relatively healthy manner. 

In time, whole populations might live mostly in virtual environments without any significant increase in health problems. The benefits of physical exercise and fresh air will still apply, and exercise has.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

In my opinion, the term "screens" is unhelpful. Long before the social media age and the pandemic, people sat at home glued to TV screens for hour after hour.  There are three main purposes of looking at a screen, for information, social connection and entertainment. If we divide out screen time to embrace social media and education, we are putting them to good use. And as for entertainment, this come in large part via screens since relatively early in the twentieth century.
In my opinion, screen time is as beneficial as any other leisure activity.
 The mechanics and ergonomics of screen use are another issue. Hunching over a screen is unhealthy, as is long-term squinting at a screen and its attendant physical immobility. But these are practical, not moral issues. Improved AI,  AR and robotics are likely to progressively integrate the main functions of screen time with the physical world in a relatively healthy manner. 

In time, whole populations might live mostly in virtual environments without any significant increase in health problems. The benefits of physical exercise and fresh air will still apply, and exercise has been integrated with VR.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

 The mechanics and ergonomics of screen use are another issue. Hunching over a screen is unhealthy, as is long-term squinting at a screen and its attendant physical immobility. But these are practical, not moral issues. Improved AI,  AR and robotics are likely to progressively integrate the main functions of screen time with the physical world in a relatively healthy manner. 

In time, whole populations might live mostly in virtual environments without any significant increase in health problems. The benefits of physical exercise and fresh air will still apply, and exercise has been integrated with VR and gaming since the N.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

If we divide out screen time to embrace social media and education, we are putting them to good use. And as for entertainment, this come in large part via screens since relatively early in the twentieth century.
In my opinion, screen time is as beneficial as any other leisure activity.
 The mechanics and ergonomics of screen use are another issue. Hunching over a screen is unhealthy, as is long-term squinting at a screen and its attendant physical immobility. But these are practical, not moral issues. Improved AI,  AR and robotics are likely to progressively integrate the main functions of screen time with the physical world in a relatively healthy manner. 

In time, whole populations might live mostly in virtual environments without any significant increase in health problems. The benefits of physical exercise and fresh air will still apply, but exercise has been integrated with VR and gaming since the Nintendo Wi. 

Reality and entertainment will merge in the best possible ways. Do you

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

In my opinion, the term "screens" is unhelpful. Long before the social media age and the pandemic, people sat at home glued to TV screens for hour after hour.  There are three main purposes of looking at a screen, for information, social connection and entertainment. If we divide out screen time to embrace social media and education, we are putting them to good use. And as for entertainment, this come in large part via screens since relatively early in the twentieth century.
In my opinion, screen time is as beneficial as any other leisure activity.
 The mechanics and ergonomics of screen use are another issue. Hunching over a screen is unhealthy, as is long-term squinting at a screen and its attendant physical immobility. But these are practical, not moral issues. Improved AI,  AR and robotics are likely to progressively integrate the main functions of screen time with the physical world in a relatively healthy manner. 

In time, whole populations might live mostly in virtual environments without any significant increase in health problems. The benefits of physical exercise and fresh air will still apply, but exercise has been integrated with VR and gaming since the Nintendo Wi. 

Reality and entertainment will merge in the best possible ways. Do you agree? Write me @twit

In time, whole populations might live mostly in virtual environments without any significant increase in health problems. The benefits of physical exercise and fresh air will still apply, but exercise has been integrated with VR and gaming since the Nintendo Wi. 

Reality and entertainment will merge in the best possible ways. Do you agree? Write me @twitter_handle.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the term "screen" is unhelpful. Long before the social media age and the pandemic, people sat at home glued to TV screens for hour after hour.  

There are three main purposes of looking at a screen: for information, for social connection and foentertainment. If we divide out screen time to embrace social media and education, we are putting them to good use. And as for entertainment, this come in large part via screens since relatively early in the twentieth century.
In my opinion, screen time is as beneficial as any other leisure activity.
 The mechanics and ergonomics of screen use are another issue. Hunching over a screen is unhealthy, as is long-term squinting at a screen and its attendant physical immobility. But these are practical, not moral issues. Improved AI,  AR and robotics are likely to progressively integrate the main functions of screen time with the physical world in a relatively healthy manner. 

In time, whole populations might live mostly in virtual environments without any significant increase in health problems. The benefits of physical exercise and fresh air will still apply, but exercise has been integrated with VR and gaming since the Nintendo Wi. 

Reality and entertainment will merge in the best possible ways. Do you agree? Write me @twitter_handle.
